texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: NOTE: The opinions shared in this post are mine alone and are not related to my employer in any way.
texts.text: NOTE: The opinions shared in this post are mine alone and are not related to my employer in any way.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The first  OpenStack Project Teams Gathering (PTG)  event was held this week in Atlanta. The week was broken into two parts: cross-project work on Monday and Tuesday, and individual projects Wednesday through Friday. I was there for the first two days and heard a few discussions that started the same way.
texts.text: The first  OpenStack Project Teams Gathering (PTG)  event was held this week in Atlanta. The week was broken into two parts: cross-project work on Monday and Tuesday, and individual projects Wednesday through Friday. I was there for the first two days and heard a few discussions that started the same way.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Everyone keeps saying OpenStack is dead.
texts.text: Everyone keeps saying OpenStack is dead.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Is it?
texts.text: Is it?

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: OpenStack isn't dead.  It's boring.
texts.text: OpenStack isn't dead.  It's boring.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: "The report of my death was an exaggeration"
texts.text: "The report of my death was an exaggeration"

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Mark Twain  said it best , but it works for OpenStack as well. The news has plenty of negative reports that cast a shadow over OpenStack's future. You don't have to look far to find them:
texts.text: Mark Twain  said it best , but it works for OpenStack as well. The news has plenty of negative reports that cast a shadow over OpenStack's future. You don't have to look far to find them:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: [<RawText children="HPE and Cisco Moves Hurt OpenStack's Public Cloud Story (Fortune)">]
texts.text: [<RawText children="HPE and Cisco Moves Hurt OpenStack's Public Cloud Story (Fortune)">]

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: [<RawText children='Is Cisco killing off its OpenStack public cloud? (Computer Business Review)'>]
texts.text: [<RawText children='Is Cisco killing off its OpenStack public cloud? (Computer Business Review)'>]

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: [<RawText children='OpenStack still has an enterprise problem'>]
texts.text: [<RawText children='OpenStack still has an enterprise problem'>]

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This isn't evidence of OpenStack's demise, but rather a transformation. Gartner called OpenStack a  "science project"  in 2015 and now 451 Research Group is  saying something very different :
texts.text: This isn't evidence of OpenStack's demise, but rather a transformation. Gartner called OpenStack a  "science project"  in 2015 and now 451 Research Group is  saying something very different :

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: 451 Research Group estimates OpenStack's ecosystem to grow nearly five-fold in revenue, from US$1.27 billion market size in 2015 to US$5.75 billion by 2020.
texts.text: 451 Research Group estimates OpenStack's ecosystem to grow nearly five-fold in revenue, from US$1.27 billion market size in 2015 to US$5.75 billion by 2020.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: A 35% CAGR sounds pretty good for a product in the middle of a transformation. In Texas, we'd say that's more than enough to  "shake a stick at" .
texts.text: A 35% CAGR sounds pretty good for a product in the middle of a transformation. In Texas, we'd say that's more than enough to  "shake a stick at" .

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: The transformation
texts.text: The transformation

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: You can learn a lot about the transformation going on within OpenStack by reading analyst reports and other news online. I won't go into that here since that data is readily available.
texts.text: You can learn a lot about the transformation going on within OpenStack by reading analyst reports and other news online. I won't go into that here since that data is readily available.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Instead, I want to take a look at how OpenStack has changed from the perspective of a developer. My involvement with OpenStack started in the Diablo release in 2011 and my first OpenStack Summit was the Folsom summit in San Francisco.
texts.text: Instead, I want to take a look at how OpenStack has changed from the perspective of a developer. My involvement with OpenStack started in the Diablo release in 2011 and my first OpenStack Summit was the Folsom summit in San Francisco.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Much of the discussion at that time was around the "minutiae" of developing software in its early forms. We discussed topics like how to test, how to handle a myriad of requirements that constantly change, and which frameworks to use in which projects. The list of projects was quite short at that time (there were only 7 main services in Grizzly). Lots of effort certainly poured into feature development, but there was a ton of work being done to keep the wheels from falling off entirely.
texts.text: Much of the discussion at that time was around the "minutiae" of developing software in its early forms. We discussed topics like how to test, how to handle a myriad of requirements that constantly change, and which frameworks to use in which projects. The list of projects was quite short at that time (there were only 7 main services in Grizzly). Lots of effort certainly poured into feature development, but there was a ton of work being done to keep the wheels from falling off entirely.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The discussions at this week's PTG were very different.
texts.text: The discussions at this week's PTG were very different.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Most of the discussion was around adding new integrations, improving reliability, and increasing scale. Questions were asked about how to integrate OpenStack into existing enterprise processes and applications. Reliability discussions were centered less around making the OpenStack services reliable, but more around how to increase overall resiliency when other hardware or software is misbehaving.
texts.text: Most of the discussion was around adding new integrations, improving reliability, and increasing scale. Questions were asked about how to integrate OpenStack into existing enterprise processes and applications. Reliability discussions were centered less around making the OpenStack services reliable, but more around how to increase overall resiliency when other hardware or software is misbehaving.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Discussions or arguments about minutiae were difficult to find.
texts.text: Discussions or arguments about minutiae were difficult to find.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Boring is good
texts.text: Boring is good

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I'm not trying to say that working with OpenStack is boring.  Developing software within the OpenStack community is an enjoyable experience. The rules and regulations within most projects are there to prevent design mistakes that have appeared before and many of these sets of rules are aligned between projects. Testing code and providing meaningful reviews is also straightforward.
texts.text: I'm not trying to say that working with OpenStack is boring.  Developing software within the OpenStack community is an enjoyable experience. The rules and regulations within most projects are there to prevent design mistakes that have appeared before and many of these sets of rules are aligned between projects. Testing code and providing meaningful reviews is also straightforward.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: However, the drama, both unproductive and productive, that plagued the project in the past is diminishing. It still exists in places, especially when it comes to vendor relationships. (That's where most open source projects see their largest amounts of friction, anyway.)
texts.text: However, the drama, both unproductive and productive, that plagued the project in the past is diminishing. It still exists in places, especially when it comes to vendor relationships. (That's where most open source projects see their largest amounts of friction, anyway.)

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This transformation may make OpenStack appear "dead" to some. The OpenStack community is solving different problems now. Many of them are larger and more difficult to solve. Sometimes these challenges take more than one release to overcome. Either way, many OpenStack developers are up for these new challenges, even if they don't make the headlines.
texts.text: This transformation may make OpenStack appear "dead" to some. The OpenStack community is solving different problems now. Many of them are larger and more difficult to solve. Sometimes these challenges take more than one release to overcome. Either way, many OpenStack developers are up for these new challenges, even if they don't make the headlines.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: As for me:  bring on the boring . Let's crush the hard stuff.
texts.text: As for me:  bring on the boring . Let's crush the hard stuff.
